pullrequest.title: Utilities for test suites, PY2 constant, minor version bump, smarter check_version()

content.raw:
The version check change was motivated by a problem with the Qt5 transition. At the moment if you run @PhyNerd's Qt5 fork of qtutils, but you have mainline BLACS, you expect a version exception saying that BLACS requires qtutils < 2.0. However, if you run the following:


```
#!python

from labscript_utils import check_version

import PyQt4.QtGui
check_version('qtutils', '1.0', '2.0')
```

You get this:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "65.py", line 4, in <module>
    check_version('qtutils', '1.0', '2.0')
  File "/home/cjb7/labscript_suite/labscript_utils/__init__.py", line 39, in check_version
    version = __import__(module_name).__version__
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/qtutils/__init__.py", line 24, in <module>
    from qtutils.qt.QtCore import qInstallMessageHandler
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/qtutils/qt.py", line 57, in <module>
    check_pyqt4_api()
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/qtutils/qt.py", line 47, in check_pyqt4_api
    raise RuntimeError("qtutils only compatible with version 2 of the  PYQt4 API. Either set the API to version 2 before importing PyQt4, or import qtutils first, which will set it for you")
RuntimeError: qtutils only compatible with version 2 of the  PYQt4 API. Either set the API to version 2 before importing PyQt4, or import qtutils first, which will set it for you

```
Not very useful. This is because qtutils 2.0 sets the API version of PyQt4 prior to importing PyQt4, which is incompatible with mainline BLACS. So we don't get as far as being able to import qtutils and check its version, even though the real problem is that the version is incompatible.

After this change, check_version now has a fallback mode where if a module fails to import it nonetheless executes the module's code in a namespace it can inspect afterward, so that it can still read the version string if it is there. Then it raises the version exception, but appends the original traceback:


```
#!python
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "65.py", line 4, in <module>
    check_version('qtutils', '1.0', '2.0')
  File "/home/cjb7/labscript_suite/labscript_utils/__init__.py", line 80, in check_version
    raise VersionException(msg)
labscript_utils.VersionException: qtutils 2.0.0 found. 1.0 <= qtutils < 2.0 required.

 === In addition, the below exception was raised during import of qtutils: ===

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/cjb7/labscript_suite/labscript_utils/__init__.py", line 47, in _get_version
    module = __import__(module_name)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/qtutils/__init__.py", line 24, in <module>
    from qtutils.qt.QtCore import qInstallMessageHandler
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/qtutils/qt.py", line 57, in <module>
    check_pyqt4_api()
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/qtutils/qt.py", line 47, in check_pyqt4_api
    raise RuntimeError("qtutils only compatible with version 2 of the  PYQt4 API. Either set the API to version 2 before importing PyQt4, or import qtutils first, which will set it for you")
RuntimeError: qtutils only compatible with version 2 of the  PYQt4 API. Either set the API to version 2 before importing PyQt4, or import qtutils first, which will set it for you
```

This should make it easier to realise when a version mismatch is the problem as opposed to a problem with the actual module.
content.html:
The version check change was motivated by a problem with the Qt5 transition. At the moment if you run @PhyNerd's Qt5 fork of qtutils, but you have mainline BLACS, you expect a version exception saying that BLACS requires qtutils < 2.0. However, if you run the following:

from labscript_utils import check_version

import PyQt4.QtGui
check_version('qtutils', '1.0', '2.0')

You get this:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "65.py", line 4, in <module>
    check_version('qtutils', '1.0', '2.0')
  File "/home/cjb7/labscript_suite/labscript_utils/__init__.py", line 39, in check_version
    version = __import__(module_name).__version__
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/qtutils/__init__.py", line 24, in <module>
    from qtutils.qt.QtCore import qInstallMessageHandler
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/qtutils/qt.py", line 57, in <module>
    check_pyqt4_api()
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/qtutils/qt.py", line 47, in check_pyqt4_api
    raise RuntimeError("qtutils only compatible with version 2 of the  PYQt4 API. Either set the API to version 2 before importing PyQt4, or import qtutils first, which will set it for you")
RuntimeError: qtutils only compatible with version 2 of the  PYQt4 API. Either set the API to version 2 before importing PyQt4, or import qtutils first, which will set it for you

Not very useful. This is because qtutils 2.0 sets the API version of PyQt4 prior to importing PyQt4, which is incompatible with mainline BLACS. So we don't get as far as being able to import qtutils and check its version, even though the real problem is that the version is incompatible.

After this change, check_version now has a fallback mode where if a module fails to import it nonetheless executes the module's code in a namespace it can inspect afterward, so that it can still read the version string if it is there. Then it raises the version exception, but appends the original traceback:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "65.py", line 4, in <module>
    check_version('qtutils', '1.0', '2.0')
  File "/home/cjb7/labscript_suite/labscript_utils/__init__.py", line 80, in check_version
    raise VersionException(msg)
labscript_utils.VersionException: qtutils 2.0.0 found. 1.0 <= qtutils < 2.0 required.

 === In addition, the below exception was raised during import of qtutils: ===

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/cjb7/labscript_suite/labscript_utils/__init__.py", line 47, in _get_version
    module = __import__(module_name)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/qtutils/__init__.py", line 24, in <module>
    from qtutils.qt.QtCore import qInstallMessageHandler
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/qtutils/qt.py", line 57, in <module>
    check_pyqt4_api()
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/qtutils/qt.py", line 47, in check_pyqt4_api
    raise RuntimeError("qtutils only compatible with version 2 of the  PYQt4 API. Either set the API to version 2 before importing PyQt4, or import qtutils first, which will set it for you")
RuntimeError: qtutils only compatible with version 2 of the  PYQt4 API. Either set the API to version 2 before importing PyQt4, or import qtutils first, which will set it for you

This should make it easier to realise when a version mismatch is the problem as opposed to a problem with the actual module.

pullrequest.title: Utilities for test suites, PY2 constant, minor version bump, smarter check_version()

content.raw: merging this since it is likely to help catch any issues with upgrading to qtutils 2.0.0
content.html: merging this since it is likely to help catch any issues with upgrading to qtutils 2.0.0

pullrequest.title: Utilities for test suites, PY2 constant, minor version bump, smarter check_version()

content.raw: Mh updating qtutils without all the other pull requests is a bad idea, because it breaks filedialogues. Or are we merging those as well?
content.html: Mh updating qtutils without all the other pull requests is a bad idea, because it breaks filedialogues. Or are we merging those as well?

pullrequest.title: Utilities for test suites, PY2 constant, minor version bump, smarter check_version()

content.raw: We are. But, this pull request is important for precisely that reason: if someone updates qtutils to 2.0.0 but is on a non-qtutils 2.0.0 compatible version of say, BLACS, then with this pull request at least they'll get an error telling them to downgrade qtutils.
content.html: We are. But, this pull request is important for precisely that reason: if someone updates qtutils to 2.0.0 but is on a non-qtutils 2.0.0 compatible version of say, BLACS, then with this pull request at least they'll get an error telling them to downgrade qtutils.

pullrequest.title: Utilities for test suites, PY2 constant, minor version bump, smarter check_version()

content.raw: Well that is unexpected good news! I was expecting merges to happen in a week at the earliest ;)
content.html: Well that is unexpected good news! I was expecting merges to happen in a week at the earliest ;)

pullrequest.title: Utilities for test suites, PY2 constant, minor version bump, smarter check_version()

content.raw: Because it's a little bit of a pain in the neck to switch *back* after switching to qtutils 2.0.0, and because there is other work happening that is based on it, I figure problems will be detected just as fast if it's merged now, and that testers aren't likely to revert unless bugs are showstoppers anyway. It's nice to keep the tip of the default branch 'stable', but these changes have seen a bit of testing already so I think it's ok to take the plunge (and Phil has indicated that he doesn't mind).
content.html: Because it's a little bit of a pain in the neck to switch back after switching to qtutils 2.0.0, and because there is other work happening that is based on it, I figure problems will be detected just as fast if it's merged now, and that testers aren't likely to revert unless bugs are showstoppers anyway. It's nice to keep the tip of the default branch 'stable', but these changes have seen a bit of testing already so I think it's ok to take the plunge (and Phil has indicated that he doesn't mind).
